Award.AwardTitle: Metaplectic automorphic forms and matrix coefficients
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will explore topics in number theory and representation theory with connections to geometry, algebraic combinatorics, and statistical mechanics. Over the past several decades it has become clear that some of the deepest questions and conjectures in number theory, most notably those connected with the Langlands program, have powerful analogs in geometry and physics. However, the mechanism behind this relationship and associated conjectures remains largely mysterious. This project aims to explore possible sources of the connections by broadening the class of objects under consideration and using the winnowed set of techniques that apply to this larger class.

In particular, many of the projects proposed center around the investigation of matrix coefficients for p-adic algebraic groups and their arithmetic covers. These matrix coefficients play a key role in the construction of automorphic L-functions. Their explicit computation in the context of metaplectic covers leads to surprising connections with geometry of Schubert varieties, to various specializations of Macdonald polynomials, and to quantum groups via both canonical bases and lattice models. These will be further developed in the proposed work and a framework for classifying matrix coefficients on algebraic groups as intertwining operators for Hecke algebra modules will be pursued. New distribution results for arithmetic functions will be another byproduct of these investigations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the primary research goals of this project was to explore how techniques from physics (more precisely, statistical mechanics) could be used to study functions arising naturally in very different disciplines of mathematics -- number theory and representation theory.

In statistical mechanics, one tries to infer global behavior of a system from local interactions of particles. For example, in a thin sheet of ice, oxygen and hydrogen atoms arrange themselves into crystalline structures that attempt to minimize the amount of stored energy in the configuration. It isn't always the exact same minimal energy configuration, but rather the ones with lowest energy occur with the highest probability. Techniques for computing this probability were pioneered some 50+ years ago, and when conditions are right for computing the result, the model is termed "solvable."

This project showed that certain functions coming from representation theory (called Whittaker functions) arise as probability densities in solvable models. So we may study them using a whole range of new techniques, and derive previously unknown properties of them. This was initially discovered with Bump (at Stanford) and his former student Buciumas (now a post-doc at Queensland in Australia), and developed in subsequent papers with them and with Frieberg (Boston College), Gustafsson (Stanford), and Schultz (Wellesley College). This lead to 6 papers either published or in review, and several more in preparation.

The work was described at international conferences in Banff, Canada and Zurich, Switzerland, and at numerous seminars throughout the United States, including plenary talks at the TORA number theory series and FPSAC (the premier conference in algebraic combinatorics) and seminars like the Integrable Probability seminar at MIT. This diverse list reveals the value of these results to a wide range of mathematical audiences.

During the granting period, PI Brubaker graduated 3 PhD students, all of whom are continuing to teach mathematics at liberal arts colleges, and is currently mentoring 4 more PhD students. Three of these seven students are women, and PI Brubaker and the University of Minnesota are proud of their efforts to promote a healthy mix of student backgrounds among our PhD students. PI Brubaker also mentored math majors from underrepresented groups in their efforts to apply to graduate school (part of the F-GAP program of the Math Alliance). In particular, one such mentee matriculated to the University of Minnesota.
